message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the positive reaction to Candida albicans extract suggest an allergic reaction, which would involve the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines. Among the options, Interferon-γ is a cytokine involved in the immune response to fungal infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest an allergic reaction and the injection of Candida albicans extract is a skin test to detect delayed hypersensitivity. Among the options, only Interferon-γ is primarily involved in cell-mediated immunity, which is responsible for delayed hypersensitivity reactions like this one.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s worsening asthma control and the mold in the apartment suggest an allergic reaction. The injection of Candida albicans extract triggers a delayed hypersensitivity reaction that involves T-cells, which release cytokines such as Interferon-γ that stimulate macrophages to produce inflammation and the palpable induration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The injection of Candida albicans extract is an example of delayed type hypersensitivity reaction, and is mediated by T cells. Among the options, Interferon-γ is a key cytokine involved in this type of reaction. Tryptase is involved in type I hypersensitivity reactions, while Interleukin-10 is involved in downregulation of immune response. Superoxide anion is involved in oxidative stress and inflammation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest that she may be allergic to mold spores, which can worsen asthma control. The injection of Candida albicans extract is a skin test used to detect allergic reactions. The palpable induration of 17 mm after 48 hours suggests a positive reaction, meaning that the patient’s immune cells released cytokines, including Interferon-γ, in response to the allergen. Tryptase is released from mast cells in response to allergic reactions, but it is not relevant to this scenario. Interleukin-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that would not be released in response to an allergen. Superoxide anion is not relevant to allergic reactions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The injection of Candida albicans extract is a skin prick test used to diagnose allergies, and the palpable induration suggests a positive reaction. Interferon-γ is released in response to allergens and is responsible for the resulting immune response.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The injection resulted in a palpable induration, which indicates a delayed-type hypersensitivity (Type IV) reaction. Interferon-γ is a major mediator of this type of reaction. Tryptase is released in acute-type hypersensitivity (Type I) reactions. Interleukin-10 and superoxide anion are not strongly associated with any type of hypersensitivity reaction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The injection of Candida albicans extract stimulates a delayed type IV hypersensitivity reaction, involving T-cells and cytokines. Among the options, only Interferon-γ is produced by T-cells and is involved in the response to intracellular pathogens like fungi.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and the positive skin test suggest an allergic response to mold exposure. Interferon-γ is released from Th1 cells and is involved in the immune response against fungi. Tryptase is released from mast cells and is not involved in the immune response against fungi. Interleukin-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine and superoxide anion is a reactive oxygen species that is not involved in the immune response against fungi.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest an allergic reaction, and the injection of Candida albicans extract is likely to cause a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction. Interferon-γ is involved in the activation of macrophages and T cells in this type of reaction. Tryptase is involved in immediate-type hypersensitivity reactions, and interleukin-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that would not cause a positive skin reaction. Superoxide anion is involved in oxidative burst of phagocytic cells and would not cause a positive skin reaction.
